summary: This document is a chain of internal FBI emails from July 3, 2020, regarding a potential witness who contacted the FBI's New York Field Office via LinkedIn. The witness, a woman, claims to have information related to a rape she experienced 20 years prior that may be connected to the Epstein investigation. The emails coordinate the FBI's response and interview logistics.

persons.name: Sweeney
persons.role: Assistant Director in Charge (ADIC) of FBI New York Field Office
persons.context: The potential witness initially contacted ADIC Sweeney via LinkedIn. An FBI email sender references that 'she contacted ADIC Sweeney.'

events.title: Potential witness contacts FBI regarding Epstein case
events.description: A woman contacts the FBI's New York Field Office via LinkedIn, stating she has information potentially related to the Epstein investigation stemming from a rape she experienced approximately 20 years ago.

events.title: Alleged rape of potential witness
events.description: The emailing woman describes being raped 20 years prior to 2020 and having lived under provable online threat since then. She mentions previously trying to get justice but the climate wasn't conducive.

keyFacts: A potential witness proactively contacted the FBI's New York Field Office in July 2020 via LinkedIn, offering information related to a past rape that may connect to the Epstein investigation.
The witness describes having lived under 'provable online threat for over 20 years' since the alleged rape, though she states the threat has 'much diminished now.'
The FBI internal emails show coordination to have the Epstein investigation task force reach out to the witness, with considerations for interview method (phone vs. Zoom) and comfort level.
The witness is also waiting for Scotland Yard to find notes from over 20 years ago related to her case so she can 'finally seek justice and recompense.'
The email chain highlights the FBI's standard security protocols, with an agent stating they 'will not send a response via LinkedIn for security and legal reasons.'
